Legal_Issue: Application of the physical presence test under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Hao was absent from Canada for prolonged periods and accumulated only 972 days of presence within the required 1095-day period preceding her application
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Citizenship Judge's decision
Court_Ruling: Federal Court found the Citizenship Judge's decision reasonable
Defendant_Behavior: Frequent travel to China resulting in insufficient physical presence in Canada
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to meet statutory residency requirement for citizenship
Assessment_Factor: Number of days physically present in Canada during the four-year period prior to application
Procedural_Issue: Appeal from a Citizenship Judge’s decision to the Federal Court
Evidence_Used: Record of entry and exit dates, travel history, application documentation
Application_Basis: Physical presence test for residency calculation
Evidence_Assessed: Days of physical presence in Canada as documented in official records
Relief_Sought: Overturning of the Citizenship Judge's decision and grant of citizenship
Governing_Rule: Applicant must have been physically present in Canada for at least 1095 days within the four years preceding the application
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient documented presence in Canada to meet the 1095-day requirement
Decisional_Body: Citizenship Judge, with appeal reviewed by the Federal Court
Cause_Description: Hao's frequent travels to China prevented her from meeting the physical presence requirement for Canadian citizenship
Evidence_Handling: Calculation of presence days based on official immigration records
Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – 972 days present out of 1095 required
Evidence_Assessment: Objective assessment of physical presence using government records
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge reasonably applied the physical presence test as required by law
